title: The changing world must be embraced
text:
An artist impression of a new tower at Circular Quay Tower.
To get a city operating at peak efficiency requires all forms of government, regulators, planners and property owners, to work as one.
In reality, that never happens.
According to the NSW Minister for Planning, Rob Stokes, a capital city has three options for growth; stop growth and go into decline; stay the same and grow and plod along; or embrace change and become an influential and sustainable place to live, work and play.
"We should not as a country look to compete with each state, such as NSW versus Victoria, but look offshore and try and beat Los Angeles, New York, Dubai and Singapore, among others," the Minister told more than 600 property faithful at the Property Council of Australia's NSW event on Thursday in Sydney.
Advertisement "We, the NSW Government, have created a new Greater Sydney Commission, to look at all aspects of urban renewal, which, when done will be sustainable, efficient and will refract the benefits to everyone from city dwellers to regional areas," Minister Stokes said.
In the same genre, of having a city that works for its current citizens, but also looks to the future, the United Nations has weighed in, saying the organisations in the land, construction and real estate sector, and those working with them, must take a leading role in global efforts to drive responsible and sustainable business practices.
In conjunction with the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors (RICS), the United Nations Global Compact has issued a call to organisations in the land, construction and real estate sector, and those working with them, to take a leading role in global efforts to drive responsible and sustainable business practices.
Sean Tompkins, chief executive of RICS, who was as the launch of a new paper, "Advancing Responsible Business Practices in Land, Construction, Real Estate Use and Investment", at the UN recently, said there is a tremendous opportunity for real estate to become a driving force for a more sustainable financial, economic, social and environmental system, through collaboration and collective action.
He said the land, real estate and construction sector represents up to 70 per cent of global wealth, contributes around one tenth of the total global gross domestic product (GDP) each year and represents 7 per cent of overall employment.
The sector also has a substantial impact on land development, resource use and waste generation. There are also issues related to human and labour rights during development and construction.
Amanda Clack, RICS president elect and only second female in the role, and RICS director of strategy, Dan Cook, said, on a visit to Sydney this week, that professionals in the built environment sector must take concerted action to prepare for the unprecedented global change the sector will face up to 2030.
Ms Clack said this emerged from a new RICS report, entitled "Our Changing World: Let's be ready", which was authored by Mr Cook.
The report examines how global social and economic changes will require new skills, business models and responses to developing technologies over the next 15 years.
Mr Cook said significant shifts in demographics, levels of urbanisation and economic power will impact on how and where we live.
